content: I've just changed the tag "Set theory" to "Sets", which is already used by 7 other puzzles.
Parsing should be done using PARSER (lex+yacc) not string analysis !

The last test is ambiguous: consider the part [20;30[U]40;50]I{25;-35;0;42;47}
([20;30[ U ]40;50]) I {25;-35;0;42;47} ~~> does not contain 20
[20;30[ U (]40;50] I {25;-35;0;42;47}) ~~> contains 20
this unfortunately makes a difference on the result (as 20 is also on the right part of the expression)...

Well sir, there is a again problem with the last validator (I mean the new last one, called Everything!).
([20;30[I]40;50]U{25;-35;0;42;47}I{-3;-1})I((]-10;10[-[4;20])U[-5;5])
=([EMPTY]U{25;-35;0;42;47}I{-3;-1})I((]-10;10[-[4;20])U[-5;5])
=({25;-35;0;42;47}I{-3;-1})I((]-10;10[-[4;20])U[-5;5])
=[EMPTY]I((]-10;10[-[4;20])U[-5;5])
=[EMPTY] because Intersection with empty will always be empty

UPDATE: I removed parentheses in tests and validators where they didn't change the result.
I added the difference '-' operator, thanks to @Recher 's idea.
Now it makes parentheses actually interesting!
Nice. I like it.
What are the precedences of I and U? How do you evaluate expressions like {...} I {...} U {...} ?

Nice idea.

Raw comments:
- this lacks a mention of precedence. If I glanced at your cases properly it seems like it's always non-ambiguous. If that's the case just state so, but don't leave us wondering.
- "sets with brackets are always ordered" Errr... no! Sets are never ordered. Do you mean the set endpoints?

Cool.
I would add some tests with many unions, or many intersections, without any parenthesis. The result is not ambiguous, because unions and intersections are associative operators. 

Some things like this :
{1;2;3} I {2;3;4} I {4;5}
[0;5] U {1;10} U [-2;3]

And maybe, why not add the difference operator ?
{1;2;3} - {2;50;60} = {1;3}
(But it may raise the difficulty of the puzzle)

Thank you for your comment,
I had added a sentence to the statement to say that the parentheses in the tests and validators left no ambiguity about that, but it would indeed be more interesting to rephrase this sentence and add tests without parentheses.
Regarding the difference operator, it's a very good idea!
As long as the implementation of the solution is good, adding an operator should not make the exercise much more difficult. I will test this in a couple of days.

Thank you, I will look at that in a couple of days when I will be able to test my solution on a computer. I will update the validator if needed!
EDIT: you were right. I updated the validator. Thanks! :)

Thanks for your comment,
You have read correctly, the test cases do not show any ambiguity about the precedence of the operators.
I did not bother to inquire about it, and that's why I wrote the tests that way.
After some research, it seems that there is indeed no precedence between union and intersection operators.
But that's a good point, I'll add this clarification to the statement.
For the order of sets, you're right, I was talking about endpoints. I will try to rephrase.

Thank you for your comment,
After some research, it seems that there is no precedence between the operators. When I wrote the tests, I did not leave any ambiguity on this subject: hence, in particular, the usefulness of parentheses.
Thanks! :D

Argh, you're right!
It seems my solution didn't work for all cases.
I fixed the validator. Thanks!
There is also an extra space in the middle of the "Empty set" test (not a big deal but that's the only time that happens, so I assume it's not on purpose).
I have removed this extra space.
Why do you validate puzzles with mistakes?...
Because beside this mistake, the puzzle is ok. And since I point it out, I fully expect it to be fixed quickly.

Doesn't the H2G2 validator require to evaluate sth. like 
(...) U (...) I (...) ? Here, the precedence would make a difference.
You're right! I added parentheses to that validator. Thanks!

The nested parentheses test case has an unmatched parenthesis. I think you might want to double-check the parentheses in all the test cases. Shame on the guy who approved the puzzle without checking that.
Thanks, I fixed it. I didn't see any other test with unmatched parentheses.

The H2G2 test requires to evaluate (...) I (...) I (...). The parse tree of the expression is non-unique because evaluating either I operator first is allowed. Although here the evaluation order does not matter because of the associativity of the operation I, it would still requires the code to handle an unparanthesized (sub-)expression that has more than one top-level operator.

By the way, I do not see you provide a sample solution to the puzzle. Isn't that required? Had you had a solution I don't think the unmatched paranthesis would be overlooked.

I added parentheses in the H2G2 test.
It's strange that you don't see the sample solution because I always provide a solution *before* making the contribution public! Prodiving a solution to the contribution is not required, but I always want to make sure that I'm able to solve the problem in order to explain it best.
Maybe in my solution I handled parentheses differently than you, because the missing parentheses in the H2G2 test did not make my solution give a wrong result.
Sorry it seems that unlike the clash problems, I cannot see the sample solutions of other puzzles either. I guess your solution did not perform a strict validation of the parantheses.
